headline.main: Good News and Bad on Long-Term Care

docs.abstract: Federal tax credits for long-term care policies are increasing -- but so are prices.
docs.snippet: Federal tax credits for long-term care policies are increasing -- but so are prices.

docs.lead_paragraph: Desperately searching for any crumb of good news about long-term care, now that the Class Act appears dead, I was glad to get an e-mail from Jesse Slome, executive director of the American Association for Long-Term Care Insurance, pointing out that the I.R.S. is going to allow slightly higher tax deductions in 2012 for the smattering of people who have bought private long-term care policies.

headline.main: Good News and Bad on Long-Term Care

docs.abstract: Federal tax credits for long-term care policies are increasing -- but so are prices.
docs.snippet: Federal tax credits for long-term care policies are increasing -- but so are prices.

docs.abstract: An accord to recapitalize European banks raises questions about the measures by which banks' balance sheets are measured, and the public has a right to be skeptical, an economist writes.
docs.snippet: An accord to recapitalize European banks raises questions about the measures by which banks' balance sheets are measured, and the public has a right to be skeptical, an economist writes.

docs.lead_paragraph: 5:53 p.m. | Updated to correct reference to inflation.

docs.lead_paragraph: A modest increase in Medicare premiums will be welcome to beneficiaries and could pay political dividends to President Obama as he tries to win the votes of older Americans.

headline.seo: Medicare Premiums Rising Less Than Expected
headline.main: Rise in Medicare Premium Is Lower Than Predicted
headline.print_headline: Rise in Medicare Premium Is Lower Than Predicted

docs.abstract: Monthly Medicare premiums for most beneficiaries will rise in 2012 by $3.50, much smaller increase than had been expected; modest increase could pay political dividends to Pres Obama as he tries to win the votes of older Americans in his bid for re-election.
docs.snippet: A modest increase in Medicare premiums will be welcome to beneficiaries and could pay political dividends to President Obama as he tries to win the votes of older Americans.

docs.lead_paragraph: After UnitedHealth/Oxford dropped its opposition recently, additional health insurance carriers have dropped their objections to the public disclosure of their filings with New York State.

headline.seo: 7 More Insurers End Fight on New York State Rate Filings
headline.main: 7 More Insurers End Objections on Rate Filings
headline.print_headline: 7 More Insurers End Objections On Rate Filings

docs.abstract: Seven large health insurance carriers, following UnitedHealth/Oxford's lead, drop their objections to the public disclosure of their filings with New York State in support of rate increases; together, the eight insurers have 90 percent of the market of small group and individual insurance plans in the state.
docs.snippet: After UnitedHealth/Oxford dropped its opposition recently, additional health insurance carriers have dropped their objections to the public disclosure of their filings with New York State.

docs.lead_paragraph: Skeptics of efforts by European officials to tackle Greece’s debt burden are saying some main elements of the agreement may not be as good as they looked initially.

headline.main: Gauging the Fallout of Another Rescue
headline.print_headline: Gauging the Fallout of Another Rescue: Harsh Realities May Challenge Initial Enthusiasm

docs.abstract: Stocks rally on news of broad European plan to fix sovereign debt problem, but critics are quick to discourage euphoria; say fix is tenuous at best and may not deliver necessary relief to Greece; point to several credit markets, including Italian bonds, in which there was no significant response to announcement of plan.
docs.snippet: Skeptics of efforts by European officials to tackle Greece’s debt burden are saying some main elements of the agreement may not be as good as they looked initially.

byline.contributor: Landon Thomas Jr. and Jack Ewing contributed reporting.
byline.original: By NELSON D. SCHWARTZ and ERIC DASH

docs.lead_paragraph: Three lawyers respond to an Op-Ed essay that argued that law degrees should not be required to practice law.

headline.main: Weighing the Value of a Law Degree
headline.print_headline: Weighing the Value of a Law Degree

docs.snippet: Three lawyers respond to an Op-Ed essay that argued that law degrees should not be required to practice law.

docs.lead_paragraph: Some railroad workers who were collecting more than $100,000 in government payments and claimed to be in severe pain when moving regularly played tennis and golf, law enforcement officials said.

headline.main: 11 Charged in L.I.R.R. Disability Fraud Plot
headline.print_headline: Charges for 11 in Disability Fraud Plot at L.I.R.R.

docs.abstract: Eleven people are charged in enormous fraud scheme in which hundreds of Long Island Rail Road workers falsely claimed to have disabling injuries, with some of them collecting tens of thousands of dollars in annual pensions; law enforcement officials say many employees who claim to be too disabled to stand, sit or walk spend time playing golf and tennis.
docs.snippet: Some railroad workers who were collecting more than $100,000 in government payments and claimed to be in severe pain when moving regularly played tennis and golf, law enforcement officials said.

byline.original: By WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM and MOSI SECRET

docs.lead_paragraph: If you have heard it once, you have heard it hundreds of times. "The United States spends too much on health care." This is not a partisan point. You can hear this from Republicans as well as Democrats. "We know that our families, our economy and our nation itself will not succeed in the 21st century if we continue to be held down by the weight of rapidly rising health care costs," President Obama said in 2009. Representative Paul D. Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin, agrees: "There is no serious dispute - on either side of the aisle."

headline.main: Spending More Doesn't Make Us Healthier

docs.abstract: Few understand how much we spend on health care, how much we need to spend to provide quality care, and the difference between the two.
docs.snippet: Few understand how much we spend on health care, how much we need to spend to provide quality care, and the difference between the two.
